ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Abnormal ripple patterns with enhanced regularity and continuity in a bulk metallic glass induced by femtosecond laser irradiation

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory for Advanced Metals and Materials
Affiliation.OrgName: University of Science and Technology Beijing

Affiliation.OrgDivision: National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Power Beam Processes
Affiliation.OrgName: Beijing Aeronautical Manufacturing Technology Research Institute

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Transient Optics and Photonics
Affiliation.OrgName: Xi’an Institute of Optics and Precision Mechanics of Chinese Academy of Sciences

Affiliation.OrgDivision: National Center for Materials Service Safety
Affiliation.OrgName: University of Science and Technology Beijing

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Two types of abnormal ripple patterns: classical ripples (C-ripples) with continuous ridges and unclassical ripples (U-ripples) with regular micropores were investigated in a Zr-based bulk metallic glass (Zr-BMG) after femtosecond laser beam irradiation. U-ripples with a period of
$$\sim $$
∼
1,600 nm and the orientation nearly parallel to the polarization of laser beam were observed to form gradually on the top of C-ripples with the effective pulse number. Micropores created by the superposition of C-ripples and U-ripples had an average diameter of
$$\sim $$
∼
750 nm nearly equal to the period of C-ripples (
$$\sim $$
∼
720 nm) and ran along parallel lines in the grooves of U-ripples. Both U-ripples and C-ripples in Zr-BMG showed significant microstructural differences comparing with those in a conventional Zr-based alloy with the same composition and processing conditions, including much more regular and continuous ridges. The results indicate that the amorphous structure in Zr-BMG plays a key role in the uniform morphology of laser-induced structures.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Laser-induced periodic surface structures (LIPSS) have been of great interests due to its theoretical significance in laser-matter interaction and potential application in surface technology with submicron scale [1–6]. The ripple structures, resulting from the interaction of intense laser beam and materials, have been observed extensively in various kinds of solid materials including metals [1–3], semiconductors [4, 5] and dielectrics [6] by using continuous and pulse laser sources. Investigations of ripple patterns have been carried out in terms of properties of the laser beam, excitation of surface plasmon polaritons, and material ablation mechanisms [7–9]. The essential parameters for controlling the formation of ripples have been put forward involving the state of laser polarization, wavelength, pulse duration, laser fluence, and pulse number [1, 6, 10–16]. Even though the formation and features of ripple structures have been studied extensively for several decades, few studies have focused on the influence of material structure on ripples. Besides basic features of ripples such as the period and direction, their regularity and continuity are also very important characteristics and the fabricating process of these patterns are required to be determined. To our best knowledge, there have, as yet, been no detailed experimental investigations focusing on the regularity and continuity of ripples from the viewpoint of the influence of material structure.

Metallic glasses, which are prepared by vitrifying melted alloy, represent a new class of structural and functional materials with extraordinary properties including high strength at low temperature and superplasticity in undercooling region, along with a number of superior chemical and physical properties [17]. This kind of material has disordered atomic structure in long range and unique glass-to-supercooled liquid transition, which are fundamentally different from conventional metals and alloys. The present study reports our finding of femtosecond laser-induced surface structures in a Zr-based bulk metallic glass (Zr-BMG) and its crystallized Zr-BMG (Zr-based alloy, Zr-BA). It was shown that two types of abnormal ripple patterns with much more significant regularity and continuity were observed in Zr-BMG compared with those in Zr-BA.

Section1.Para:

(at.%) was produced by arc melting under a purified Ar atmosphere and dropping into a copper mold. Zr-BA was obtained by annealing Zr-BMG at 520
$$^{\circ }$$

C for 50 h in order to produce a crystalline structure. The surface of selected samples was polished by conventional metallographic procedure with a final polish of 0.05
$$\upmu $$
μ
m suspended alumina powder.

The ablation experiments in both Zr-BMG and Zr-BA were conducted in air using a commercially available Ti:sapphire laser system, generating linearly polarized laser pulses at a center wavelength of
$$\lambda =800$$
λ = 800
nm with the pulse duration of 120 fs and a maximum repetition rate of 1 kHz. The sample was mounted on a computer-controlled x–y–z translation stage with a spatial resolution of 125 nm and placed perpendicular to the laser beam direction close to the focal plane of a lens with a focal length of 120 mm. The experiments were carried out by translating the sample relative to the stationary laser beam with the feedrate
$$(v)$$
( v )
varying between 0.125 and 10 mm/s. The laser fluence (peak value,
$$\varPhi $$
Φ
) of the incident radiation could be varied using a polarizer combined with a half wave plate. The corresponding effective pulse number (
$$N$$
N
) was calculated based on the feedrate and the focused beam diameter (
$$\sim $$
∼
70
$$\upmu $$
μ
m). After laser processing, the sample was subjected to ultrasonic cleaning in ethanol for 5–10 min. The microstructural characteristics of laser irradiation regions were examined by a ZEISS SUPRA 55 field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) operated in secondary electron (SE) imaging mode and an Agilent Technologies 5500 atomic force microscope (AFM).

Section1.Para:
Figure 1 is a SEM image, showing the typical microstructure in Zr-BA after femtosecond laser irradiation at the laser fluence

$$\sim $$

690 nm approximately equal to the laser wavelength (800 nm) and their orientation is perpendicular to the polarization of laser beam, similar to the ripple pattern produced in almost every type of materials [1–6]. Here, these ripples are called classical ripples (C-ripples).

Figure 2a shows the typical microstructure in Zr-BMG after femtosecond laser irradiation at the same conditions of laser processing as those in Zr-BA. The direction of the ripple pattern is also exhibited to be perpendicular to the polarization of laser beam. The morphology of these ripples is much more regular and their ridges seem to be continuously straight lines compared with those in Zr-BA (Fig. 1). Figure 2b is a 3D AFM profile image of this abnormal ripple structure in Zr-BMG. Their period of
$$\sim $$
∼
720 nm is nearly the same as C-ripples in Zr-BA. Thus, they are named as C-ripples with continuous ridges.

While with increasing the effective pulse number from 59 to 197, another abnormal morphology of the ripple pattern (U-ripple) in Zr-BMG is generated gradually on the top of C-ripples with continuous ridges. Figure 3a is a SEM image, showing the typical microstructure of this abnormal pattern. In comparison to the C-ripples with continuous ridges as shown in Fig. 2a, the parallel ridges of these U-ripples exhibit an angle of
$$\sim $$
∼
15
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
with respect to the laser polarization direction besides stretching continuously and regularly. Furthermore, regular micropores appear to exist along parallel lines in the grooves of U-ripples. Here, they are termed as U-ripples with regular micropores. Figure 3b, c is an AFM 3D profile image of the U-ripples with micropores and a cross-section profile along the path marked in Fig. 3b, respectively. The period of U-ripples is measured to be
$$\sim $$
∼
1,600 nm, and it is about two times the wavelength (800 nm) of incident laser beam. The micropores have an average diameter of
$$\sim $$
∼
750 nm. It should be noted that the similar ripple pattern is also obtained in Zr-BA, but those ripples do not have continuous ridges and regular micropores, unlike those in Zr-BMG (Fig. 3a).

The formation of C-ripples with continuous ridges and U-ripples with micropores in Zr-BMG after femtosecond laser irradiation is investigated with respect to the laser fluence
$$(0 \le \varPhi \le 2.0~\hbox {J}/\hbox {cm}^{2})$$
( 0 ≤ Φ ≤ 2.0
J /
cm 2
)
and the effective pulse number
$$(0 \le N \le 560)$$
( 0 ≤ N ≤ 560 )
in more details. Figure 4 is a map of the relationship between femtosecond laser-induced surface morphology and laser processing parameters (laser fluence and effective pulse number). The boundaries of regimes in the fluence versus pulse number plot are defined by the experimental data points using round symbols. This map can be divided into five zones: no-ablation, no-LIPSS, C-ripples with continuous ridges (like Fig. 2), U-ripples with regular micropores (like Fig. 3), and severe ablation. There is no direct transition occurred from no-LIPSS to U-ripples with regular micropores. In the severe ablation zone, the surface started to be severely ablated due to large pulse number and high laser fluence, resulting in the disappearance of LIPSS. It is worthy of noting that all the transition boundaries in this map depend on both the laser fluence and the effective pulse number.

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: Like those observed in Zr-BA as shown in Fig. 1, wavelength-scale C-ripples with the orientation perpendicular to the polarization of laser beam have been reported in other metals, alloys and semiconductors [1–4]. The mechanism responsible for their formation refers to locally modulated ablation with a spatial modulation of the deposited optical energy. This modulation occurs as a result of the partial transformation of incident laser radiation into surface electromagnetic waves and the interference of incident laser radiation with surface electromagnetic waves [1, 5, 7, 11–14].

In the current study, the U-ripples (Fig. 3a) have much larger period (
$$\sim $$
∼
1,600 nm) than the laser wavelength (800 nm) and their ridge direction exhibits only several degrees off with respect to the laser polarization direction, and these features are obviously different from the C-ripples (Figs. 1, 2). Ridges with similar features to those of U-ripples are also observed in indium phosphide and silicon [18, 19]. According to one model, these ridges are formed by the surface capillary waves, which involve femtosecond-laser induced melting and resolidification. The initiation of capillary waves may be associated with the temperature gradient in the melted surface. This temperature gradient can be influenced by the non-uniformity of laser energy absorption, which results from the spatially Gaussian intensity distribution of the focused laser beam combined with the distinctive surface roughening and near-surface material modification upon multiple-pulse irradiation [19]. These capillary waves could lead to the formation of U-ripples when they are frozen on the surface during the resolidification of the melted layer.

In the present study, the following characteristics should be also noted, including (1) U-ripples formed on the top of C-ripples (similar phenomena have been reported in details for silicon in the previous study [19]) and (2) micropores with the average diameter of
$$\sim $$
∼
750 nm nearly equal to the period of C-ripples and running along parallel lines in the grooves of U-ripples. These observations suggest that micropores are generated due to the superposition of the C-ripples and U-ripples.
Fig. 4
Occurrence of femtosecond laser-induced surface morphology in Zr-BMG with respect to the laser fluence and the effective pulse number. The boundaries of regimes in the fluence vs. pulse number plot are defined by the experimental data points using round symbol

A striking feature of two types of abnormal ripple patterns in Zr-BMG is the enhanced regularity and continuity. In the present study, the obvious microstructure difference between Zr-BMG and Zr-BA indicates that the amorphous structure in Zr-BMG played a key role in the uniform morphology of both abnormal ripple patterns. Laser-induced phase and ablation behaviors have been reported to depend on the structure of materials [20–22]. Liu et al. [20] observed that the amorphization in single crystal silicon occurred more readily on (111) surfaces as opposed to (100) surfaces during picosecond laser irradiation. Mannion et al. [22] found that the ablation thresholds induced by femtosecond laser were very different in common metals and alloys (stainless steel, copper, niobium, and titanium), for example, the single-shot ablation threshold for copper was about three times higher than that for niobium. Furthermore, the above ablation rates of single pulse by femtosecond laser, which were dominated by the value of the optical and/or energy penetration depth, were based on the state and distribution of electrons in materials. These suggest that irregular morphological change on material surface after laser irradiation can be produced arising from local inhomogeneous material factors: including compositions, crystal structure and orientations, or electrons. Moreover, the detect-initiated generated excitation of surface plasmon polaritons plays a dominant role during the initial stage of ripple structures in femtosecond-laser irradiation [11, 18]. Different types of defects in materials may change the excitation conditions of seed carriers at the onset of plasma generation. The absence of an ordered atomic-scale structure, crystallites, grain boundaries, and dislocations in the amorphous structure of Zr-BMG results in the homogeneous and isotropic characteristics down to the atomic scale [17]. These unusual properties compared to conventional crystalline materials should lead to more uniform modulated intensity field for C-ripples or capillary waves for U-ripples, especially better homogeneous laser-induced ablation. All these can result in the laser-induced ripples with more regularity and better continuity.

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para: In summary, two types of abnormal ripple patterns including C-ripples with continuous ridges and U-ripples with regular micropores were observed in Zr-BMG after femtosecond laser irradiation (120 fs, 800 nm). Microstructural investigations indicates that U-ripples were formed on the top of C-ripples with sufficiently high laser pulses, and the micropores, running along parallel lines in the grooves of U-ripples, were produced due to the superposition of the C-ripples and U-ripples. The map of occurrence for both C-ripples and U-ripples in Zr-BMG and their parametric dependence was established. Both abnormal ripple patterns in Zr-BMG showed significant regular and continuous ridges than those in conventional Zr-BA. The obvious microstructural difference between Zr-BMG and Zr-BA indicates that amorphous structure plays a key role in the uniform morphology of laser-induced structures.
